These are mimeographed study guides for courses
taught by television in the Detroit public schools.
They tell classroom teachers in advance that on
March 10, the television teacher in ninth-grade
World History will discuss the Thirty Years’ War.
... The guide to an eighth-grade science lesson on
chemical changes suggests that teachers ask their
classes to read about Priestly, Lavoisier, and Dal¬
ton and to identify the black material in a burnt
pie crust. . . . The guide for third-grade French
lists in the new vocabulary for Unit 6, “The
Market,” the French for words like “basket,”
“salesman,” and “I buy.”
Detroit began telecasting courses in 1955. In 1957, j
it joined the National Program in the Use of Tel¬
evision in the Public Schools, supported by the 1
Ford Foundation and the Fund for the Advance- ]
ment of Education. It is fairly typical of school
systems using television for direct teaching for
credit: ETY neither blankets the school system|
nor is it a token activity. Ninety-six of Detroit’s
280 schools use one or more TV courses.
The ETV budget for the Detroit schools is about
$200,000 a year out of a total school budget of
$125 million. ETV is conducted by twenty-three j
on-camera teachers and twenty-four production,!
evaluation, and supervisory personnel. No stu-j
dent receives more than thirty minutes of tele-1
vised instruction a day. In the ten to twenty-five
minutes before or after the televised lesson, class¬
room teachers further explain the lessons, handle j
pupils’ questions, review and test, and present
new material. On-camera teachers spend the full
week preparing for and delivering a single tele-1
vised course. They meet with classroom teachersj
in four-week summer workshops and monthly
during the school year to plan the course and re¬
view the effectiveness and shortcomings of the
televised presentations.
The televised classes are larger than normal, aver-]
aging 150 pupils. As few as two classroom teach¬
ers can conduct such classes. Students are tested,
before and after television courses, in intelligence,
achievement in subject matter, and listening skill
